qas.question: Which writer and artist was behind the Sub-Mariner?
What was Marvel's major offshoot with Westerns, war stories, and monster comics called?
What was Dan DeCarlo's spooky but humorous comic aimed at kids called?
DeCarlo also penned a knock-off of what teen comic superstar?
What was the name of DeCarlo's main character in his humorous teen series?
When did the Archie Andrews comics run?
What company successfully revived several superheroes?
What was another name for the Human Torch?

context: <a1_0>Atlas<a1_0/>, rather than innovate, took a proven route of following popular trends in television and movies—Westerns and war dramas prevailing for a time, drive-in movie monsters another time—and even other comic books, particularly the EC horror line. Atlas also published a plethora of children's and teen humor titles, including Dan DeCarlo's <a2_0>Homer the Happy Ghost<a2_0/> (à la Casper the Friendly Ghost) and <a4_0>Homer Hooper<a4_0/> (à la <a3_0>Archie Andrews<a3_0/>). <b8_0>Atlas<b8_0/> unsuccessfully attempted to revive superheroes from <b7_0>late <b5_0>1953<b5_0/> to mid-1954<b7_0/>, with the Human Torch (art by <b9_0>Syd Shores<b9_0/> and Dick Ayers, variously), the Sub-Mariner (drawn and most stories written by <a0_0>Bill Everett<a0_0/>), and Captain America (writer Stan Lee, artist John Romita Sr.). Atlas did not achieve any breakout hits and, according to <b6_0>Stan Lee<b6_0/>, Atlas survived chiefly because it produced work quickly, cheaply, and at a passable quality.
